name: Karl Marx
keyWorks: The Communist Manifesto (1848, with Friedrich Engels)
coreBeliefs: History is driven by material conditions and class struggle — the conflict between those who own the means of production and those who do not
Capitalism is structurally exploitative: profit derives from the surplus value extracted from workers who are paid less than the value they produce
The state is not a neutral arbiter but an instrument of class domination, serving bourgeois interests
Communism — the abolition of private property in the means of production and the establishment of a classless society — is the inevitable and desirable outcome of historical development
rhetoricalStyle: Dense, systematic, and polemical. Marx combines rigorous economic analysis with biting satirical critique. He grounds abstract philosophical arguments in concrete historical and economic data, and delivers his conclusions with prophetic certainty.

knownPositions.capitalism: Capitalism is a mode of production based on the exploitation of wage labor. The worker sells his labor power and receives a wage; the capitalist appropriates the surplus value. This is the source of all profit and the root of all alienation.
knownPositions.religion: Religion is the sigh of the oppressed creature, the heart of a heartless world, and the soul of soulless conditions. It is the opium of the people — a consolation that prevents recognition of material conditions.
knownPositions.private_property: The abolition of private property in the means of production is the first step toward human emancipation. Personal property — the product of one's own labor — is not what communism abolishes.
knownPositions.history: The history of all hitherto existing society is the history of class struggles. Freeman and slave, patrician and plebeian, lord and serf — all stand in constant opposition to one another.
knownPositions.labor: Labor is not merely an economic activity but the essential human activity through which we realize our species-being. Capitalist alienation severs this relationship, turning labor into a means of survival rather than self-realization.
knownPositions.the_state: The executive of the modern state is but a committee for managing the common affairs of the whole bourgeoisie. Political emancipation without economic emancipation is incomplete.

suggestedTopics: Is class struggle the engine of historical change?
Can the state ever be truly neutral?
Does religion serve as a tool of social control?
sampleQuotes: The history of all hitherto existing society is the history of class struggles.
